Introduction

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is a viral infection characterized by oral ulcers and a rash on the hands and feet.  HFMD primarily affects infants and young children and is caused by enteroviruses, most commonly coxsackievirus A serotypes.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



HFMD is caused by enteroviruses (eg, coxsackievirus, enterovirus A71), which enter the body through the ingestion of viral particles from infected individuals.  The virus can be shed from respiratory secretions, oral secretions, fecal material, or vesicular fluid.  After it enters the body, the incubation period is 3-5 days.  During this period, the virus replicates in the gastrointestinal tract and lymphoid tissues before disseminating through the reticuloendothelial system and bloodstream to other organs (eg, heart, liver, brain, skin).  The characteristic clinical manifestations result from viral replication and immune-mediated inflammation at these distant sites.



Risk factors for HFMD include:



  • Young age (most commonly affects children age <7)

  • Close contact with infected individuals (eg, day care centers, schools)

  • Poor hygiene practices

  • Warm and humid climate

Clinical presentation



Patients with HFMD typically present with:



  • Oral enanthem:  Patients typically have a sore throat and pain with swallowing.  Infants may have irritability and increased drooling due to pain.  Examination typically shows vesicles and ulcers (

    image 1
    ), usually on the tongue, buccal mucosa, and palate.

  • Skin exanthem:  A macular or maculopapular rash (

    image 2
    ) progressing to vesicles (
    image 3
    ) that erode (
    image 4
    ) may be seen on the hands, feet, and buttocks.  Less commonly, vesicles may be seen on the face or torso.  The rash is typically nonpruritic but may be painful.



Systemic (eg, fever, malaise) or gastrointestinal (eg, vomiting, diarrhea) symptoms may also be present.

Differential diagnosis



The following illnesses may present similarly to HFMD:



  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection:



    • Primary HSV infection: can cause gingivostomatitis, resulting in oral lesions similar to those seen in HFMD.  Although some overlap may occur in vesicle distribution, vesicles presenting on the anterior oral mucosa (

      image 5
      ), particularly the lips and gingiva, are much more likely to be due to HSV.  Patients with HSV infection may develop herpetic whitlow, but this usually appears as clusters of vesicles on the fingers, not diffuse papules/blisters on the hands, feet, or buttocks.

    • Patients with underlying atopic dermatitis are at risk for developing an HSV-induced skin complication (ie, eczema herpeticum), which presents with multiple tender vesicles and ulcers at the eczema sites (

      image 6
      ).

  • Aphthous stomatitis (

    image 7
    ):  presents with shallow, painful ulcers with a gray-white base tend to occur along the anterior oral mucosa (eg, lips, buccal mucosa).  No fevers or other systemic symptoms are seen.

  • Chickenpox (varicella):  is a viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus.  Symptoms begin with fever, followed by a generalized vesicular rash that progresses to pustules and crusts (

    image 8
    ); intraoral lesions can also occur.  Although chickenpox lesions can occur anywhere on the body, they tend to be concentrated on the trunk and face.  Involvement of the palms and soles is extremely rare, and lesions are pruritic, unlike the nonpruritic exanthem in HFMD.

  • Scarlet fever:  is a delayed-type immune response to a pyrogenic exotoxin produced by Streptococcus pyogenes.  Patients usually have a history of streptococcal infection (eg, pharyngitis, cellulitis) and then develop a diffuse, erythematous, papular rash that has a sandpaper quality (

    image 9
    ).  Vesicles are not typically seen.  In addition, scarlet fever is often associated with other symptoms, such as strawberry tongue (
    image 10
    ) and circumoral pallor (
    image 11
    ).

  • Human herpesvirus 6 infection (roseola infantum):  causes high fever followed by an erythematous maculopapular rash (

    image 12
    ) that starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities.  The rash spares the palms and soles and is not associated with an oral enanthem.

Diagnostic evaluation



Diagnosing HFMD is primarily clinical and is based on the characteristic signs and symptoms.  Laboratory tests are not routinely required for the diagnosis.  However, when the clinical presentation is atypical or confirmation is needed, viral culture or PCR testing may be performed on throat swabs, stool samples, or vesicular fluid.

Prognosis



The prognosis for uncomplicated HFMD is excellent, with symptoms typically resolving within 7-10 days.  However, viral shedding in the stool may continue for >6 weeks, which can propagate transmission.



The following complications, although rare, may develop in some patients, particularly those with HFMD caused by enterovirus A71:



  • Neurologic:  Enteroviruses are the most common viruses, leading to aseptic meningitis.  Infants are at greatest risk for developing this type of meningitis.  Other neurologic complications from HFMD include acute flaccid paralysis and brainstem encephalitis.

  • Cardiovascular:  Myocarditis may also occur as a rare complication of HFMD, presenting with signs of heart failure (eg, tachycardia, dyspnea, tachypnea).

  • Nail dystrophy:  Some patients may develop onychomadesis (

    image 13
    ) (separation of the proximal nail plate from the nail bed) in multiple digits.  This tends to occur 1-2 months after HFMD and is caused by certain strains of coxsackievirus that directly infect the nail matrix, causing temporary disruption of nail plate growth.  Other, less severe manifestations include Beau lines (
    image 14
    ), transverse lines in the nail plate that result from sudden interruption of nail synthesis.

Management



Management of HFMD is primarily supportive, focusing on relieving symptoms and preventing complications.  Treatment options include symptomatic relief with analgesics for pain and antipyretics for fever.  Patients must maintain adequate hydration; those who cannot do this may require hospitalization for parenteral fluids.  In addition, hospitalization is indicated in those who develop severe complications (eg, myocarditis, meningitis).  Because patients can continue shedding the virus for >6 weeks after recovery, measures to prevent infection spread (eg, strict hand hygiene, particularly when changing diapers) should be reinforced.

Summary



Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (
